values.text: Good for you!

An artificial neural network is an interconnected group of nodes, inspired by a simplification of neurons in the human brain. Every circular node represents an artificial neuron and the link between them represents a connection from the output of one artificial neuron to the input of another. Let me find you a photo that can illustrate it. Wait a second

Input layer is very simple, basically it is where the initial data is fed to the neural network model.

Here is the definition of all the layers shown in the picture:
Input layer â€” initial data for the neural network.
Hidden layers â€” intermediate layer between input and output layer and place where all the computation is done.  It is where the process of weighting, summing, biasing and applying
an activation function happens. 
Output layer â€” produce the result for given inputs.
If we have many hidden layers we are touching a subject of deep learning. Do you want to go deeper into this?
Output layer produces the result for the given inputs provided.
Do you want to continue watching the video, should I explain all the layers, or do you want me to explain a specific layer?

This is the intermediate layer between input and output layers and the place where all the computation is done. It is where the process of weighting, summing, biasing and applying
an activation function is computed for all the neurons in a layer.
Well, you know there can be more than one hidden layer, it can be many layers deep. If we have many hidden layers we are touching a subject of deep learning. Do you want to go deeper into this?
I'm glad to hear.

Way to go! Good job!

A weight represents the strength of the connection between units. If the weight from node 1 to node 2 has greater magnitude, it means that neuron 1 has greater influence over neuron 2. 
A weight decides how much influence the input will have on the output.
A weight brings down the importance of the input value. Weights near zero means changing this input will not change the output. 



Bias is like the intercept added in a linear equation. It is an additional parameter which is used to adjust the output along with the weighted sum of the inputs to the neuron. 
Here is a representation to understand better...

By the way, the values of these parameters before learning starts are initialised randomly (this stops them all converging to a single value). Then when presented with data during training, they are adjusted towards values that have correct output

We refer to â€˜deep learningâ€™ because the neural networks have various (deep) layers that enable learning. Deep learning allows machines to solve complex problems even when using a data set that is very diverse, unstructured and inter-connected. The more deep learning algorithms learn, the better they perform.

A real life example of deep learning practice can be how deep learning is used in developing self-driving cars. 
There's not just one AI model at work as an autonomous vehicle drives down the street. Some deep-learning models specialize in streets signs while others are trained to recognize pedestrians. As a car navigates down the road, it can be informed by up to millions of individual AI models that allow the car to act.

I have an interesting article about how to build CNN (Convolutional Neural Networks) which is one of the key techniques in Deep Learning for autonomous driving I will share with you if you are interested in digging deeper in the topic.
https://towardsdatascience.com/deep-learning-for-self-driving-cars-7f198ef4cfa2

Actually, a lot of tech companies tend to use AI and ML interchangeably. 
Artificial intelligence, or AI, is the science and engineering of making computers behave in ways that, until recently, we thought required human intelligence.  
However, machine learning is a branch of AI and it means the study of computer algorithms that allow computer programs to automatically improve through experience.

Also, in the video she discussed two types of machine learning techniques: Statistical andÂ non-statistical techniques. Do you want me to explain that or would you rather continue watching the video and see if you have any other questions for me?

Unlike statistical ML algorithms like Decision Trees and Support Vector Machines that are strongly rooted in the field of statistics. 
Non-Statistical ML techniques have no origins in statistics. In this video we are focusing on the way Artificial Neural Networks work. Do you know how it works?

Activation function, or also called transfer function, decides, whether aÂ neuronÂ should be activated or not by calculating weighted sum and further adding bias with it. 
It is basically the final step where the hidden layer performs a mathematical modification to the input so you can actually use the information collected from the unlabeled/raw data to classify what you have found. 
Activation functions are used to introduce non-linearity to neural networks.
Did you understand the role of the bias and weights in the hidden layer?
